section.title: cherrypy.request.remoteAddr
section.para: This attribute is a string containing the IP address of the client.

section.title: cherrypy.request.remoteHost
section.para: This attribute is a string containing the remote hostname of the client.

section.title: cherrypy.request.headerMap
section.para: This attribute is dictionary containing the received HTTP headers.

section.title: cherrypy.request.requestLine
section.para: This attribute is a string containing the first line of the raw HTTP request.

section.title: cherrypy.request.simpleCookie
section.para: This attribute is a SimpleCookie instance from the standard library's Cookie module which contains the incoming cookie values from the client.

section.title: cherrypy.request.remoteAddr
section.para: This attribute is a string containing the IP address of the client.

section.title: cherrypy.request.rfile
section.para: This attribute is the input stream to the client. See cherrypy.request.processRequestBody for more information.

section.title: cherrypy.request.processRequestBody
section.para: This attribute should be accessed during the beforeRequestBody stage of the request (if you don't know what this means, read the section on filters). This specifies whether or not the request's POST data will be parsed into the cherrypy.request.paramMap. It defaults to true for POST requests, but when false, cherrypy.request.rfile will be readable by the exposed method. Otherwise, rfile is completely read before control is handled to the exposed method.

section.title: cherrypy.request.method
section.para: This attribute is a string containing the HTTP request method, such as GET or POST.

section.title: cherrypy.request.protocol
section.para: This attribute is a string containing the HTTP protocol of the request in the form of HTTP/x.x

section.title: cherrypy.request.queryString
section.para: This attribute is a string containing the query string of the request (the part of the URL following '?').

section.title: cherrypy.request.path
section.para: This attribute is a string containing the path of the resource the client requested.

section.title: cherrypy.request.paramMap
section.para: This attribute is a dictionary containing the query string and POST arguments of this request.

section.title: cherrypy.request.base
section.para: This attribute is a string containing the root URL of the server.

section.title: cherrypy.request.browserUrl
section.para: This attribute is a string containing the URL the client requested.

section.title: cherrypy.request.objectPath
section.para: This attribute is a string containing the path of the exposed method that will be called to handle this request. This is usually the same as cherrypy.request.path, but can be changed in a filter to change which method is actually called.

section.title: cherrypy.request.originalPath
section.para: This attribute is a string containing the original value of cherrypy.request.path, in case it is modified by a filter during the request.

section.title: cherrypy.request.originalParamMap
section.para: This attribute is a string containing the original value of cherrypy.request.paramMap, in case it is modified by a filter during the request.

section.title: cherrypy.request.scheme
section.para: This attribute is a string containing the URL scheme used in this request. It is either "http" or "https".

section.title: cherrypy.response.headerMap
section.para: This attribute is a dictionary with automatically titled keys. It holds all outgoing HTTP headers to the client.

section.title: cherrypy.response.simpleCookie
section.para: This attribute is a SimpleCookie instance from the standard library's Cookie module. It contains the outgoing cookie values.

section.title: cherrypy.response.body
section.para: This attribute is originally just the return value of the exposed method, but by the end of the request it must be an iterable (usually a list or generator of strings) which will be the content of the HTTP response.

section.title: cherrypy.response.status
section.para: This attribute is a string containing the HTTP response code in the form "### Reason Phrase", i.e. "200 OK"
